description: The objective of this course is to study the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory. The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas. This course serves as an extension of FNCE 100. Some areas of financial management not covered in FNCE 100 are covered in FNCE 203. These may include leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and some other selected topics. Other areas that are covered in FNCE 100 are covered more in depth and more rigorously in FNCE 203. These include investment decision making under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure, pricing of selected financial instruments and corporate liabilities, and dividend policy.
name: ADVANCED CORP FINANCE

values.comments:
The objective of Finance 203 is to study the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory. The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas. This course serves as a complement and supplement to FNCE 100. Some areas of financial management not covered in FNCE 100 are covered in FNCE 203. These may include leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and other selected topics. Other areas that are covered in FNCE 100 are covered more in depth and more rigorously in FNCE 203. These include investment decision making under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure, pricing of selected financial instruments and corporate liabilities, and dividend policy.

Student feedback on this course was mixed. While some students found the case component of the class was weighted too heavily and required too much time, others believed that cases made them “feel ready for Finance interviews and internships.” Students agreed that the cases required a significant time commitment and a lot of work. Many indicted displeasure with the format of the course, noting that grading was based solely on pop quizzes and group work. 

Student opinion of Professor Kihlstrom was also mixed. One student mentioned that he was “a wonderful professor” and did “a great job engaging student interest,” and another mentioned that he was “very, very accessible” and “friendly” during office hours. Several other students explained that the professor’s teaching style was dry and could have done a better job “spicing up the material.”

According to one student, the course offered a “broad picture” of various topics in finance and readings were “extremely interesting,” while others found the material somewhat boring and repetitive. One student suggested that Finance 203 was a nice primer for other upper level Finance classes, such as Finance 207.
